East Khasi Hills.title: East Khasi Hills, Meghalaya
info: Home to Shillong, the state capital, often referred to as the 'Scotland of the East'.
Features Cherrapunji (Sohra) and Mawsynram, which are among the wettest places on Earth.
Known for its stunning waterfalls like Nohkalikai Falls and Elephant Falls.
The district is famous for its living root bridges, a unique bio-engineering marvel.
Inhabited predominantly by the Khasi tribe.

tourist_places.name: Nohkalikai Falls
tourist_places.location: Near Cherrapunji, East Khasi Hills, Meghalaya

tourist_places.name: Double Decker Living Root Bridge
tourist_places.location: Nongriat Village, Near Cherrapunji, East Khasi Hills, Meghalaya

West Khasi Hills.title: West Khasi Hills, Meghalaya
info: The largest district in Meghalaya by area.
The district headquarters is at Nongstoin.
Known for its rich deposits of minerals like coal and limestone.
The region has picturesque landscapes with hills, valleys, and rivers.
Nongkhnum River Island, the second largest river island in Asia, is a major attraction.

tourist_places.name: Nongkhnum River Island
tourist_places.location: Near Nongstoin, West Khasi Hills, Meghalaya

East Jaintia Hills.title: East Jaintia Hills, Meghalaya
info: Carved out of the Jaintia Hills district in 2012.
The district headquarters is at Khliehriat.
Known for its extensive network of caves, including Krem Liat Prah, the longest natural cave in India.
The district is rich in coal and limestone reserves, leading to significant mining activities.
Inhabited by the Jaintia (Pnar) people.

tourist_places.name: Krem Liat Prah
tourist_places.location: Shnongrim Ridge, East Jaintia Hills, Meghalaya

West Jaintia Hills.title: West Jaintia Hills, Meghalaya
info: The district headquarters is Jowai.
Home to the Nartiang Monoliths, the largest collection of monoliths in a single area.
The Krang Suri waterfall is one of the most beautiful and popular waterfalls in Meghalaya.
The Syntu Ksiar, a vast pool on the Myntdu River, is a significant local site.
Inhabited by the Jaintia (Pnar) tribe, known for their unique culture and the Behdeinkhlam festival.

tourist_places.name: Krang Suri Falls
tourist_places.location: Near Jowai, West Jaintia Hills, Meghalaya

Ribhoi.title: Ri-Bhoi, Meghalaya
info: Often considered the gateway to Meghalaya as it borders Assam.
The district headquarters is at Nongpoh.
Known for the Umiam Lake (Barapani), a vast man-made reservoir and a major tourist attraction.
The district is a hub for pineapple cultivation.
The Lum Nehru Park, located near Umiam Lake, is a popular picnic spot.

West Garo Hills.title: West Garo Hills, Meghalaya
info: The headquarters, Tura, is the largest town in the Garo Hills region.
Home to Nokrek Biosphere Reserve, a UNESCO World Heritage Site.
Nokrek Peak is the highest point in the Garo Hills.
The district is predominantly inhabited by the Garo tribe.
The Wangala (Hundred Drums) festival is the most important festival of the Garos.

East Garo Hills.title: East Garo Hills, Meghalaya
info: The district headquarters is Williamnagar, named after the first Chief Minister of Meghalaya.
The Simsang River, the longest river in the Garo Hills, flows through this district.
Known for its rich biodiversity and dense forests.
Dominated by the Garo tribal community.
The region has several historical and mythological sites.

tourist_places.name: Domre Falls
tourist_places.location: Near Williamnagar, East Garo Hills, Meghalaya

South Garo Hills.title: South Garo Hills, Meghalaya
info: Known for the Balpakram National Park, famous for its unique landscape and biodiversity.
Balpakram is often referred to as the 'Land of Spirits' and is steeped in Garo mythology.
The Siju Cave (Bat Cave) is one of the longest cave systems in the Indian subcontinent.
The district headquarters is at Baghmara.
It is a hotspot for wildlife, including elephants, tigers, and rare species of birds.

tourist_places.name: Siju Cave
tourist_places.location: Near Siju, South Garo Hills, Meghalaya

North Garo Hills.title: North Garo Hills, Meghalaya
info: Carved out of the East Garo Hills district in 2012.
The district headquarters is at Resubelpara.
Known for its rubber and tea plantations.
The region has several picturesque waterfalls and streams.
The area is predominantly inhabited by the Garo people.

tourist_places.name: Naphak Lake
tourist_places.location: Near Resubelpara, North Garo Hills, Meghalaya

South West Khasi Hills.title: South West Khasi Hills, Meghalaya
info: Created in 2012 by bifurcating the West Khasi Hills district.
The district headquarters is at Mawkyrwat.
Known for its rugged terrain and rich uranium deposits.
The region is culturally rich with Khasi traditions.
It has a long international border with Bangladesh.

tourist_places.name: Jakrem Hot Springs
tourist_places.location: Near Mawkyrwat, South West Khasi Hills, Meghalaya

South West Garo Hills.title: South West Garo Hills, Meghalaya
info: One of the newest districts, created in 2012 from West Garo Hills.
The district headquarters is at Ampati.
The district has a large plain area bordering Bangladesh.
It is an important region for agriculture and trade with Bangladesh.
The area is predominantly inhabited by the Garo tribe.
